panels.description: How long it takes to process a record as perceived by users. Itâ€™s the difference between the record timestamp and the time at which the record was fully processed by the Kafka Streams processor node. So it shows not only how long it took for Kafka Streams to process the record, but also how long it took for Kafka Streams to pick up the record.
panels.title: e2e latency

panels.description: Execution time to process records.
panels.title: Process latency

panels.description: Active Tasks
panels.title: Tasks

panels.description: How many instances are active
panels.title: Instances

panels.description: How many threads are active
panels.title: Threads

panels.description: number of kafka client instances connected (producer and consumer)

targets.expr: count (kafka_consumer_connection_count{ job=~"$job", instance=~"$instance"}) + count (kafka_producer_connection_count{ job=~"$job", instance=~"$instance"} )

panels.title: Clients

panels.description: Total number of connections for all producer and consumer clients.

targets.expr: sum (kafka_consumer_connection_count{ job=~"$job", instance=~"$instance"}) + sum (kafka_producer_connection_count{ job=~"$job", instance=~"$instance"})

panels.title: Connections

panels.description: how many records are being processed per second.
panels.title: Process Rate

panels.description: The rate at which Kafka Streams source nodes are consuming messages from Kafka topics.
panels.title: Messages in

panels.description: The rate at which Kafka Streams sink nodes are producing messages to Kafka topics.
panels.title: Messages out

panels.description: The rate at which punctuators are triggered.
panels.title: Punctuation rate

panels.description: An overview of how Kafka Streams spends its execution time. Active actions are processing messages, punctuating and committing. The remaining time is typically spend polling for data.
panels.title: CPU utilization

panels.description: The average and maximum execution time across all punctuators
panels.title: Punctuation latency

panels.description: How many keys are stored in the state stores. Every task maintains its own part of a state store. This panel shows the sum of those keys, for every state store.
panels.title: Estimated keys in state stores

panels.description: The rate of PREFIX SCAN operations on the state stores.
panels.title: State store PREFIX SCAN rate

panels.description: The rate of PUT operations on the state stores.
panels.title: State store PUT rate

panels.description: The rate of GET operations on the state stores.
panels.title: State store GET rate

panels.description: The rate of PREFIX SCAN operations on the state stores.
panels.title: State store RANGE rate

panels.description: The rate of DELETE operations on the state stores.
panels.title: State store DELETE rate

panels.description: The rate of FETCH operations on the state stores.
panels.title: State store FETCH rate

panels.description: The rate of PREFIX SCAN operations on the state stores.
panels.title: State store ALL rate

panels.description: The current number of iterators on a state store that have been created, but not yet closed. If this keeps going up, then you probably didnâ€™t close a state store iterator in your code and have a memory leak.
panels.title: Open iterators

panels.description: The average time spent between creating an iterator and closing it.
panels.title: Iterator duration

panels.description: Off-heap memory used for RocksDBâ€™s block cache, summed by Kafka Streams state store. This cache is used by RocksDB to efficiently process read requests, without having to read data from disk. If it reaches the default of 50MB per RocksDB store, then you might have to increase it for better read performance. When increasing it, watch out for the memory configuration of your server/container to avoid OOM issues, as this is off-heap memory.
panels.title: Block Cache Capacity

panels.description: Off-heap memory used for RocksDBâ€™s block cache, summed by Kafka Streams state store. This cache is used by RocksDB to efficiently process read requests, without having to read data from disk. If it reaches the default of 50MB per RocksDB store, then you might have to increase it for better read performance. When increasing it, watch out for the memory configuration of your server/container to avoid OOM issues, as this is off-heap memory.
panels.title: Block Cache Usage

panels.description:
Off-heap memory used for RocksDBâ€™s memtables, summed by Kafka Streams state store. 
RocksDB buffers writes into these memtables as new records are put into the state store. Every RocksDB store by default has 3 active memtables, of 16MB each. These memtables get flushed as they fill up. When it reaches the maximum (48MB for all 3 memtables combined), there might be performance issues with flushing the memtables to disk.
panels.title: Memtables size by state store

panels.description: Off-heap memory used for RocksDBâ€™s block cache, summed by Kafka Streams state store. This cache is used by RocksDB to efficiently process read requests, without having to read data from disk. If it reaches the default of 50MB per RocksDB store, then you might have to increase it for better read performance. When increasing it, watch out for the memory configuration of your server/container to avoid OOM issues, as this is off-heap memory.

targets.expr: avg by(state_id, store_type) (kafka_stream_state_block_cache_usage{job=~"$job", instance=~"$instance", thread_id=~"$thread"} / kafka_stream_state_block_cache_capacity{job=~"$job", instance=~"$instance", thread_id=~"$thread"})

panels.title: Block Cache Capacity
